Class exCanvas

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Canvas
          online.common.exCanvas
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.Observer, javax.accessibility.Accessible, DeferredEventHandler, ImageLoader.ImageConsumer, ImageLoaderProtocol, CanvasProtocol, OnlineConstants, RepaintManager.RepaintHelper, URLs
Direct Known Subclasses:
commonCanvas, lobbyCanvas, UCTTreeViewer

extends java.awt.Canvas
implements java.util.Observer, OnlineConstants, DeferredEventHandler, CanvasProtocol, URLs, ImageLoaderProtocol, ImageLoader.ImageConsumer, RepaintManager.RepaintHelper, java.awt.image.ImageObserver

deferredEvents

public DeferredEventManager deferredEvents
asynchronous events such as menu selections and input from the network should be synchronized with the game even loop using the deferredEvents queue

runThread

public java.lang.Thread runThread
this is the thtead executing the viewerRun method. Since the basic model requires that everything happens in this thread, code where you suspect "leakage" in to other processes can check.

See Also:
ViewerRun(int)

theChat

public commonChatApplet theChat
the chat window associated with this window

sharedInfo

public exHashtable sharedInfo
a #exHashtable of things shared among many parts of the program. In games, this is primarily used for parameters passed from the lobby.

theRoot

public RootAppletProtocol theRoot
the root applet for the game. Some image and sound operations have to be provided by the applet. There are also some error reporting utilities here.

this contains the translations for all the messages in the user interface.

StartDragging

public abstract void StartDragging(HitPoint hp)
StartDragging is called from the default version of MouseMotion(int, int, online.common.OnlineConstants.mouseState) when the mouse button is down and the mouse moves, or when the mouse button is released (possibly without being moved). The intended interface for your canvas to use StartDragging to trigger events which involve picking up and moving an object.

Parameters:
hp -
See Also:
StopDragging(online.common.HitPoint)

StopDragging

public abstract void StopDragging(HitPoint hp)
StopDragging is called when the mouse button transitions from down to up. The intended interface is to use StopDragging to trigger clicks on buttons and other objects that do not move.

Parameters:
hp -
See Also:

MouseMotion

public HitPoint MouseMotion(int eventX,
                            int eventY,
                            OnlineConstants.mouseState upcode)
This is called from the viewer event loop when there is any mouse activity that needs to be handled. The mechanics guarantee that every "down" will be matches by an "up", and every down or up will be followed by a "move".

Parameters:
eventX - is the mouse x
eventY - is the mouse y
upcode - is an integer code indicating the state of the mouse, one of OnlineConstants.mouseState

drawFixedElements

public void drawFixedElements(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                              boolean complete)
this is the prototype method which may be overridden. Normally it allocates an offscreen bitmap using RepaintManager.createAllFixed(int, int), which is cached and reused. This calls drawFixedElements(java.awt.Graphics) to do the actual drawing.

complete - force a complete redraw

ViewerRun

public void ViewerRun(int waitTime)
this is the run loop for the window. All significant events should occur here. Actions due to network, mouse, or keyboard should be deferred and handled here. Canvas painting is also deferred and handles here.

About the only thing that doesn't happen here is activity by robots to search for next moves.

Specified by:
ViewerRun in interface CanvasProtocol
See Also:
handleDeferredEvent(java.lang.Object), RepaintManager.paintCanvas(java.awt.Graphics, boolean, online.common.HitPoint)

draw an image with smooth scaling and caching

Parameters:

drawImage

public java.awt.Rectangle drawImage(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                                    java.awt.Image im,
                                    double[] scale,
                                    int x,
                                    int y,
                                    double boxw,
                                    double xscale,
                                    double jitter,
                                    java.lang.String text,
                                    boolean artCenterText)
this is the primary method to draw an images with transparent backgrounds on a canvas. The images are clipped to a slightly smaller box to avoid the "edge garbage" bug.

Another feature of this interface is that the images are displayed quickly at first, then "slow scaled" to the desired size.

Parameters:
gc - the graphics context
im - the image to draw
scale - the x,y offset and scale factor to expand or shrink the image
x - the x coordinate to draw at
y - the y coordinate to draw at
boxw - the box width to draw
xscale - separate x scale for nonuniform scaling on the x axis
jitter - percentage of size to jitter the image position
text - text to draw over the image
artCenterText - if true center the text in the box, otherwise at the art center
Returns:
returns the actual rectangle where the image was drawn

                         java.lang.Object last)

adjustScales2

public void adjustScales2(double[] pscale,
                          java.lang.Object last)

getAltChipset

public int getAltChipset()
This is the key method for defining alternate sets of artwork based on the StockArt class. At a very low level, just before the canvas draws an image based on StockArt, it calls getAltChip. These two methods work together to make appropriate substututions in the artwork.

The meaning of the alternate chip index, and the nature of the substitutions made, are a matter of agreement between your canvas and chip classes.

Returns:
a chipset index (default 0)
See Also:
getAltChip

drawSprites

public void drawSprites(java.awt.Graphics gc)

addSprite

public void addSprite(SpriteProtocol ss)
add a new sprite to the active list. All the added sprites are activated at the same time, so a start time of 0 will be the same for all sprites. Sprites are drawn in reverse order that they were added to the list, so the first sprite added will be drawn last.

Parameters:
ss -
